title: Opinion | Fake Invasion, Real Defense Cuts
text:
In July , the Supreme Court allowed the Pentagon to begin spending the $2.5 billion — which came from programs for hiring military personnel, buying weapons and supporting the Afghan security forces — while litigation over that matter continues .

Mr. Trump may think he has the upper hand because he can claim to his most faithful followers that their beloved wall is being built, but that project, never widely popular, has lost favor with the general public.

And his plan for 450 miles of new fencing and other barriers by 2020 is way behind schedule: Since Mr. Trump took office, little more than 60 miles of replacement barrier have been built, all in areas that previously had border infrastructure, according to The Washington Post.

The president’s end-run has angered Democrats and some Republicans, and it will complicate congressional decision-making this fall on defense and appropriations bills, especially if Mr. Trump continues to expect Congress to replace the reallocated funds.

Now that the Pentagon has made public the $3.6 billion in military construction projects that would go unfunded, the political blowback could grow as Americans digest what is being sacrificed for the wall.

Puerto Rico, which was pummeled by Hurricane Maria in 2017 and is often disparaged by Mr. Trump, and Guam, which is even less of an administration priority, are the hardest hit. Most of Puerto Rico’s defunded projects were related to hurricane recovery at military bases.

Other big losers are Virginia, where two warehouses for hazardous materials and a ship maintenance facility are on the list of cuts; New York, where an engineering center and a parking structure at West Point will take a hit; and New Mexico, where an information systems facility and a special operations center are on the chopping block.
description: Trump has treated the Pentagon budget as sacrosanct, unless he can raid it to pay for his wall.
